Authors:
Merlin M. White, Laia Guardia Valle, Robert W. Lichtwardt,
Augusto Siri, Douglas B. Strongman, Robert T. William, Justin Gause,
Eric Dennis Tretter
Title:
New species and emendations of Orphella, taxonomic and
phylogenetic reassessment of the genus to establish the Orphellales, for
stonefly gut fungi with a twist
Abstract:
We consolidate and present data for the sexual stage of
five North American species of Orphella, a fungal member of the
trichomycetes that until now was placed within the Harpellales.
Emendations to three species accommodate the newly recognized features,
including not only the coiled zygospores and accompanying cells but also
other morphological traits not provided in the original descriptions for
O. avalonensis, O. haysii and O. hiemalis. We also describe Orphella
cataloochensis, with the aid of sexual features especially, from
collections in The Great Smoky Mountains, USA and two provinces, Nova
Scotia and Ontario, in Canada as well as O. pseudoavalonensis and O.
pseudohiemalis from collections in Cascade Range, Oregon, USA. Key
morphological features for all known species of the genus are summarized
and reviewed, with illustrations of some of the North American taxa to
update and complete the literature. The entire suite of morphological
characters is discussed with emphasis on species relationships and
hypotheses on possible vicariant origins. We also present a molecular
phylogeny based on 18S and 28S nuclear rDNA, which confirms that
Orphella is a unique evolutionary lineage separate from Harpellales, and
we create a new order, Orphellales, to accommodate it. With the
combination of sexual features, now known for twelve of the fourteen
species of Orphella, and new molecular data, the group is more fully
characterized in a way that will help inform ongoing and future efforts
to better understand their relationships, origins, evolutionary history
and toward a more complete picture of the genealogy of life.
